course.subject: MATH
course.name: Statistical Inference
course.description: Sampling theory, order statistics, limiting distributions, point estimation, confidence intervals, hypothesis testing, non-parametric methods.
course.prerequisites: MATH 2421 OR MATH 2431

reviews.author: Jeff Sun
reviews.title: I know it was a popular course, but it is a disaster if taught by YCW
reviews.comment_content:
1. Preliminary
2. Point estimation
3. Hypothesis testing

**Seems** identical to before, but he will add R language in this theoretical course.

Note that YCW seems to have reordered the materials taught in 2411, 2421, and 3423, therefore he might have covered some materials in 2411/21 that is supposed to cover in 3423, and you will be at a loss. For me, I didn't take 2411 prior to this semester due to the time clash issues and take 2411 taught by another professor (which is also a disaster as 2411 is dictated by YCW), and I took 2431 instead of 2421 before, therefore sometimes I was like "what the hell" and sometimes I was like "EXM, r u kidding? Wasn't this covered in 2431?"

You are advantaged if you take YCW's version of 2411 and 2421, he seems to have designed this.
reviews.comment_teaching:
For those who don't speak Cantonese: his English sounds the same as Cantonese, and he will get stuck every one or two words and says "ahh...". Moreover, since this course is online (during the pandemic), he teaches in an **empty** classroom with a poor Internet connection and masks on, which further blurs his voice. This makes his lectures almost impossible to comprehend. Moreover, his handwriting is not comprehensible either. Therefore, it's very difficult to pay attention all the time.

His math is usually not very rigorous.

But he intentionally leaves blanks in his "colorful" notes to force you to suffer his lectures, but still, only 1/3 of us comes.

Unfortunately, Prof. Wong, who used to teach this course, seems to retire soon and she won't be teaching this course again, so I suspect that YCW will be teaching this course for the following semesters.
reviews.comment_grading:
BAD AND TOTALLY OPAQUE
You will have 3 assignments in total, contributing to 35% of the grade.

For the rest 65%, it's the worst part of the course, the final exam. First, we did not get enough exercise because of the small number of problems presented in either lectures, assignments, or tutorials. Second, he intentionally annoys you in every part of the exam. I believe that he is fanatic about R, and therefore, he makes u write and run R codes during the final, and he will give the data in IMAGE format, therefore, you have to key in each number but cannot do copy and paste! Some problems are unnecessarily tricky by making the parameters negative, and the others are confusing by themselves because I cannot understand what he wants or what it is about. I was disgusted after the final, literally.

The letter grades are released without releasing the final grades. I guess he just looks at the papers and assigns a letter grade by intuition, because if I were a grader, conditioning on such a poorly designed and totally ungradable paper, I may have to do that.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 poorly designed assignments, 4~5 questions each.  

You need time to review what he talked about because it's hard to understand what he says.

Lack of other forms of exercise makes us learn nothing, it's a WASTE of resources and time!

reviews.author: kptss88
reviews.title: the heaven for stat. lovers, the hell for others
reviews.comment_content:
CAUTION: DON'T register this course if you don't need!!! All statistical techniques you need can mostly learn from other fundamental stat. courses, which are also most of the pre-requisites of other stat.-related courses. What appears in this course is just the proof or technique used to derive the materials in those 2 courses.

Brief summary:
Part 1: Introduction (Basic knowledge will be used throughout this course)
- MGF, CLT, Multivariate normal distribution, Chi-square, t, F distribution & related confidence intervals, Order statistics

Part 2: Parameter Estimation (mostly focus on point estimation)
- Methods of finding estimators (MME, MLE), CRLB, requirements for the 'best' estimator: MVUE & UMVUE

Part 3: Hypothesis Testing
- introduction to H. test, Neyman-Pearson Lemma, UMP test, Likelihood ratio test, Pearson's goodness-of-fit test

Exams are cumulative that the part 1 and the first half of part 2 are included in the midterm and the final mainly examines the remains. The understanding of concepts may be a difficulty but for the exams, they are just step-by-step stuff.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Wong is one of the good professors among the MATH department. She knows that this is a hard course for students (not for me) so she first suggested us to drop this course if you couldn't handle with what is taught in the add-drop period. Meanwhile, she demonstrated examples and explanations with details by hand-writing. I think this teaching strategy is more appropriate than just speaking with a monotone and powerpoints in a math course teaching proofs.
She is also kind for the students who want to ask for help. Just ask her if you can't understand the materials.

However, the speed may be a little bit slow since she has to make sure we can all understand the examples and the concepts. Attendance somehow is needed because she will only upload the hand-writing notes to who attend the lectures, and you may not able to get the full picture just from the notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments x 6 5%
Classwork quizzes 5%
(after the deadline of the assignments)
Mid-term Examination: 25% or 35%
Final Examination: 65% or 55%

Prof. Wong said she will focus on the classwork rather than the assignments that the questions are similar but more difficult. you may easily get full marks in the assignments as long as you finish it but not in the classwork.
reviews.comment_workload:
It is too much for me in this semester because the assignments are almost bi-weekly as well as the classwork. Maybe since I skipped rather many lectures, especially after the midterm, it always took me 2-3 nights to finish each assignment and prepare for the classwork. The exams also cost a lot of time to do the revision because each contains many formulae, procedures, theorems in the lecture notes.

In addition, please remember that you will take this course, together with MATH 3033 Real Analysis, a "hell" for most of the MATH student, in the fall term of your 3rd year for the SF-track, so take care of your grades.

reviews.author: æ•¸å­¸ç ”ç©¶ç”Ÿ
reviews.title: Professor is nice but the course needs more examples
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers several things related to statistics and distributions. At first, Professor made revisions on things related to MATH 2421, especially the 2 or more random variables, joint distributions and MGF.
Then the Central Limit Theorem and introduced new technique called Delta Method, which is used to find the distribution for any parameters for a specific distribution for big n.

And MME, MLE and CRLB those things that may be abstract but needs you to think.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor likes writing her notes on pieces of A4 sheets and asked us to sign our names on the name list each class. She will send her handwriting notes to those who signed their names on the name list. Those useful materials are her handwriting, if you just study with her notes that posted on her website cannot understand much. For each class, I have to ask her some questions since it's not easy to understand what's going on for the materials.
reviews.comment_grading: Still learning, but don't know the grading system. But normally most of the people cannot get a good result in midterm and final( I don't know, just guess), mean is low and with 12 SD in the midterm this year.
reviews.comment_workload: Quite good if you just focus on this course. A homework assignment every two weeks and there are three classwork in total which calculated for 5% in your total grade.

reviews.author: elessar
reviews.title: Very helpful in terms of basic Statistics
reviews.comment_content:
Three chapters are covered.
1. A revision of some basic distribution, stressing on Gaussian distribution and related distributions.
2. Parameter Estimation: Maximum Likelihood Estimation, MSE, Cramer-Rao Lower Bound, Uniformly Minimum Variance Unbiased Estimators
3. Hypothesis Testing. Definition, Neyman-Pearson Theorem, Likelihood Ratio Test, Pearson's Goodness of fit test.

To be honest, there is not much content. Plus the fact proofs of the theorems are not taught. So those seeking advanced mathematical proofs may skip this course actually.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Wong explains things quite well. Her basic teaching style is to rewrite her lecture slides again in class. So actually skipping courses is OK I guess. Despite so, she explains things very well.
reviews.comment_grading:
I heard that professor Wong give bad grades. But it turned out fine for me personally.
Midterm mean27/full mark54
FInal mean 42/full mark100
Quiz1 mean 8/full mark14
Quiz2 mean 7/full mark14
Quiz3 mean 7/full mark14
Grading Schemes homnework5% Quiz 5% Midterm(0.25/0.3) Final(0.65/0.6)
I got 46 in midterm and 77 in the final. Got an A.
reviews.comment_workload: In fact, the workload is OK. Homework twice a week. As long as one goes through the lecture slide before the homework or quiz, he or she will be fine. There is little need to do extra exercises.

reviews.author: poonlam167
reviews.title: ycw is so trash
reviews.comment_content:
quite hard if you are not familiar with Math 2411

most topic is an in-depth teaching for Math 2411, explaining the concept of the stat method taught in 2411 and require proving it in hw and exam

require to understand the proof for the concept taught in Math 2411
reviews.comment_teaching:
ycw is trash,killer around 40% student failed in this course
wont give out class material online for most of the lesson
require yourself to attend the class in person for copying his hand writing notes
talk irrelevant thing during class
reviews.comment_grading:
killer
Final mean and median is 16/70
For me:over 40% and get an F for this course

reviews.author: economist
reviews.title: Hard work might (not) change your destiny
reviews.comment_content:
I suggest you refer to previous reviews so a brief overview would suffice here.
1. Some preliminary materials
(multivariate normal distribution, CLT, WLLN, Delta method, CMT, order statistics, uniqueness theorem of MGF)
2. MLE
(asymptotically normal, asymptotically consistent, asymptotically unbiased)
3. UMVUE
(fisher information, CRLB, sufficiency, completeness, exponential family, Lehmann-Scheffe Theorem)
4. LRT, UMP, MLR
reviews.comment_teaching:
As Prof. Wong Man Yu will retire, you will face YCW in decades to come.

Standard. Not that terrible as suggested by a lot of people. But you should be vigilant as there is high uncertainty when the lessons return face-to-face.
He uses a lot of drawing in lessons (which could be helpful)
There are numerous empty spaces for you to write notes (and they might appear in your exam in a different way e.g. coding with R)

His lessons are sometimes boring due to his low pitch and you could be driven to sleep.
In the beginning, his teaching quality seems acceptable but as time evolves, he begins to neglect the questions in the chatroom.
reviews.comment_grading:
Assignments: 30%
Final Exam:   70%

Some statistics:
HW1 --> Mean: 91.88 High: 100         Low: 0
HW2 --> Mean: 81.76 High: 100 Low: 0
HW3 --> Mean: 82.47 High: 100         Low: 0
Final exam --> Mean: 50.85    SD: 18.46
PS: YCW did not allow any paper checking (and you could guess the reasons)
See the distribution in the attachment!
My grade: A (Note: A range is narrower than expected)
reviews.comment_workload:
Medium.
Slightly lower than the workload in MATH 2421 (XIA DONG) as there is only three homework. But you will spend about a day in each homework as the style is weird.
PS: Previously I have not suffered from "YCW torturing" since this is my first course taught by YCW.

As there is NO mid-term, the final exam will decide your destiny and you will have no idea where is the end. Try the past paper (through different means) and also understand the steps of each question in the extra practice that YCW has given. You should definitely DO the past paper but for the extra practice, you might only need to UNDERSTAND each step in solutions and learn the tricks to save time.

The style of the final exam might be less weird than the homework but some questions require high intelligence to solve it and I suggest you skip those questions first. The tactic is not to finish all questions but to finish the questions that you could cope with. Chances are that you get a decent grade by finishing only 80% of the questions. Don't panic when you encounter strange questions (they are just the tricks YCW wants to stop you from advancing to the next easier questions).

reviews.author: Jaydencw
reviews.comment_content:
Chapter 1: Preliminary

Chapter 2: Limit Theorems

Chapter 3: Large-n Random intervals based on sample mean (and/or sample variance)

Chapter 4: What if n is not large?

Chapter 5: Two Skills on Point Estimation: MME and MLE

Chapter 6: (Locally) Best Estimator: UMVUE

Chapter 7: Hypothesis Testing: Likelihood Ratio Test

Not difficult actually.
reviews.comment_teaching: I have better to study by myself!
reviews.comment_grading:
10% participation
30% homework
60% final exam
only 2 hw which include 2 to 3 question.
final exam
mean= 13/70
See! This is YCW.
I believe many people get F in this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Actually do not have many stuff to do.
2 homework and 1 final exam.

reviews.author: luke_lu
reviews.title: YCWay or no way
reviews.comment_content:
This course covers different topics regarding how you can interpret the data you have.

Convergence in probability and distribution
The confidential interval of different statistics under different assumptions
Delta methods
Bootstrap Resampling (R coding)
Estimation methods: MME and MLE
Hypothesis Testing

and how to use R to help in the above
reviews.comment_teaching:
To be clear, I consider YCW a good professor regarding his attitude toward teaching. It seems that he did want to teach well.

But this results in his arbitrary way of teaching. He has his own idea on how to maximize teaching outcomes. In the process, the student's feeling is not his consideration.

First, he gives partial note, and give them after each class. If the point of partial notes is to make students take notes to focus, why give them after class? In addition, his note is a mixture of beautifully formatted, text typed, and handwritten parts.
Second, he (planed) to not release the recording. Luckily it is later changed. His point is that not giving recording is good for study. (which my foolish student brain can't reason why)  To compensate for this, he keeps saying we can ask him questions as others wrote. But he seems to ignore that one could ask nothing if one is confused.
Third, but not least. He requires each homework to have a 10min  recorded presentation to explain your answer. Is it really necessary if I can write out my answer on the paper?

In conclusion. YCW's teaching philosophy is to maximize pain. and hope you learn something during the process.
reviews.comment_grading:
Scheme 1: HW (35%) + Exam (65%)
Scheme 2: HW (30%) + Class participation (10%) + Exam (60%)
take the max

Attached are the statistics of the final course grade.
Unlike what people wrote, the grading this year is pretty clear. He gives much more information about the final.

In my experience, HW is easy, most people get a full mark. But the final is a total disaster, the mean of part 2(~50% of final) is 12 and std is 11.
reviews.comment_workload:
Three HWs in total, each has about 4 questions. Lite workload I would say.

BUT! you need to record a presentation to explain your solution in under 10 minutes. If you are not a math teacher, it's gonna be hard to keep it short. I doubt whether he will continue this next time.

If he does, I suggest you learn video editing a bit to avoid re-recording many times.

reviews.author: chhh
reviews.comment_content:
Theories of estimation (UMVUE) & hypothesis testing (UMP Test and Likelihood Ratio Test).
Knowledge in probability Theory are expected.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Wong is a great teacher in statistical theory. After studying her course, my understanding in statistical concepts was deepened. The course provided me with a stepping stone into the another quantitative realm.
reviews.comment_grading:
Fair grading.
Will get a B for mean.
At least 1 sd to get a A- probably.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload was kinda heavy but it actually ensured that you will understand the materials and help you pass the course.

reviews.author: cdbn
reviews.title: One of the best statistic courses in HKUST
reviews.comment_content:
è¿™é—¨è¯¾çš„ä¸»è¦å†…å®¹:
midtermå‰:
- MGF
- Central limit theorem
- Delta method
- Multivariate normal distribution
- Chi-squared, t-distributed, F distribution

reviews.author: Female
reviews.comment_content:
The course content are divided to 3 parts.
1. Central limit theorem/delta method/Moment generating function/..
2. Parameter estimation...
3. Hypothesis testing

Many proof and mathematics notations.
If you think math2421 is a boss, then I can tell you math2421 is just like a tiny baby in front of this course.
It is not a practical course. It focuses the concept of statistics so much. Pure math students may like this course.
reviews.comment_teaching:
She is a nice person and have a good spoken English but her teaching style may not fit me.
In the class, she kept talking and writing the notes but the notes are not really well-organized.
I think it is quite extreme. Some students think she is the best professor in math department. Some are not.
TA always just reading the notes once... and done...
reviews.comment_grading:
2 grading scheme
Assignments 5%
Classwork quizzes 5%
Mid-term Examination: 25% or 35%
Final Examination: 65% or 55%

Just like other math courses, mean grade is C+.
As I know, a certain amount of students failed this course as they underestimated the difficulty of this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
It's quite much, comparing with other math courses.
Assignments are difficult. But quizzes and assignments are similar.

I highly recommend you to spend 2~3hours on studying this course everyday because it is not easy to pass and understand those abstract concepts.

reviews.author: USTAsiaNo1
reviews.title: Great introductory course for inference
reviews.comment_content:
- Content

1. Some basic knowledge

revision of 2000 level course:
> F, Chi-squared, t distribution
> revision of Normal, Multi-normal
> moments
new:
> limit theorem
> converges in probability, in distribution
> slutsky's theorem, delta theorem
> order statistics, QQ plot

2. Estimator

> MLE, MME (Maximum likelihood estimator, Method of moment estimator)
> Asymptotic of MLE

> UMVUE (Uniformly minimum-variance unbiased estimator)
> Fisher information
> Information inequality

> Sufficiency
> Completeness
> relationship with existence of UMVUE
> special case of exponential family

3. Inference

> One-sided, Two-sides test
> Type I, II error
> LRT
> Asymptotic of LRT
> Asymptotic of multivariate LRT

> Power function
> UMP test (Uniform most powerful test)
> MLR (Monotonic likelihood ratio)
> Special case of exponential family

> Pearson's goodness-of-fit test

wow, what a detailed list lol
anyway, it basically covers
> estimator of parameter(s) of a distribution
> constructing a test to evaluate a hypothesis of an estimator of parameter(s) of distribution

- Comments

definitely useful in providing a good coverage and introduction of necessary knowledge for any further study in statistics
reviews.comment_teaching:
- Materials

1. Not complete

I strongly recommend you guys ATTAINING the lesson to mark down some important information like proofs and examples
The notes is designed to have some blank page left for you to mark down your own note
Basically, it is like 24xx

So,
> Go to lesson
> Take your own note

Besides the incompleteness of the note,

2. Well-designed

I think Professor Yu do a great job, with graphs and examples included in his note, basically, it is like 24xx

3. Same style as 24xx

For anyone who will take this course, I believe you guys have already known his style though 24xx, so, just make your own judgement, don't take my word

- Teaching

1. Complete

I think 90% of what he taught in the course is well-explained and proved, the contents is mostly self-sufficient.
Still, there is some advanced things will be missed like detailed proof of theorem in multivariate case, detailed proof of asymptotic properties, or using measure theory to construct the theorem.

In general, for a 3000 level course, i think it is sufficiently self-sufficient

2. Style

Again, as you guys should have took 24xx, you should know what it is

Some seem dislike his style, I personally find it good since I can understand most things he said and I don't think it is THAT boring (if you ask me to grade the boringness, it would be 4/10), maybe it varies from people to people, so, don't take my word

Just, to be honest, what you expect from a mathematics course lol
I think it is fine. Still, you should know what it is, ask yourself. :)
reviews.comment_grading:
- Scheme

35% assignments
65% final

- Statistics

mean:
Assignment 1: 44.5, full = 50
Assignment 2: 44.9, full = 50
Assignment 3: 36.3, full = 40
Final: not disclosed

me:
Assignment 1: 47
Assignment 2: 47
Assignment 3: 40
Final: not disclosed
get a A-

So, with no final exam score released, I can tell you nothing, I have to give a C as I cannot make any judgement
reviews.comment_workload:
- Course work

For the 3 assignments, I think they are not too hard
(7/10 if I have to weight it)

Still, it DOES take a while to finish since
> statistical inference question is always so long, you have to do everything step-by-step, so, it takes time!!
> you need to be careful, CAREFUL on every step!!

Anyway, you can always google for answer. Even some is quite weird, you can always find some insight from some similar questions on the web.

- Exam

1. Weird

Some question is weird
As what you experienced in 24xx, there is some problem which you cannot clearly tell what theorem to use, or what trick to use

2. Some standard problem

Some problem is just a modified version of assignment
You should be able to gain some score for sure, again, as what you experienced in 24xx

- Sum-up

Essentially, it is just a up-scaled version of 24xx, everything (surely excluding contents) is similar, you know what to expect
If you like it before, you will like 3423
If you hate it before, you will too hate 3423

end :)

reviews.author: Aaron W
reviews.comment_content:
This course is mainly focused on estimators and hypothesis testing. The general idea is that you have a known or limiting distribution but with unknown parameters, and you want to construct a good estimator for these parameters, e.g. MLE and UMVUE. Most of the course is centered around this idea, with some slight variation, e.g. bootstrapping for insufficient data, bayesian prior and posterior distributions.

Topics:
1. Limit Theorems
2. Bootstrapping
3. Statistical Decision Theory
4. MLE and UMVUE
5. Hypothesis Testing
6. Bayesian Statistics
reviews.comment_teaching:
Didn't go to any lectures so don't know much about his teaching. However, the lecture notes he provides are incomplete and a large portion are left blank, since he expects you to go to class. During class, he mostly writes over these blanks and on scratch paper, meaning I had to watch all the lecture videos when preparing for the final.

I don't know how clear his explanations were either since I was watching at 10x speed and just looking at what he wrote, but it would have been helpful if he had provided these handwritten notes to students.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading Scheme:
Assignments (x4): 35% -- Mean: 387.05/400 (96.8/100)
Final: 65%

Me:
Assignments: 395/400
Final: Unknown (not released)
Grade: A+

The final results were not released and we weren't even given the distribution of the scores. Although I knew I did well on the final, I have no idea how well I did in comparison to the rest of the class. Total mystery.

Without a midterm, the course grade was determined entirely by the performance in the final, since everyone gets full marks in the assignments (except for those that didn't hand it in). Thus, the fact that YCW didn't release the results for the final makes it impossible to judge how lenient or strict he is.
reviews.comment_workload:
The assignments had 3-4 questions each, and a lot of them are recycled from previous semesters. This means that if you have a friend or senior who took this course in a previous semester, you can just copy their solutions for most of the questions. As such, the overall workload is minimal if you have source, and I barely studied until the day before the final.

The final exam was quite mechanical and the types of questions are quite standard, e.g. finding the confidence interval for a given estimator, or applying the LRT test. We were allowed to bring one double-sided cheat sheet to the exam, so you don't really need to memorize anything. There was a couple of slightly tricky question that involved the gamma distribution and its shape and rate parameters, so make sure you write all the probability distributions on your cheat sheet.

reviews.title: Elementary statistics course

reviews.author: sleepingbag
reviews.comment_content: Some really interesting statistical methods. For DSCT students, the content of this course would contain some necessary math knowledge if you want to dig into some machine learning realms that requires a lot of math and statistics.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor YU really shows passion in teaching during the class. He used all kinds of method to make a point as clear as possible.

If you couldn't understand some points, you could ask him in class or write an email to him. He would also try his best to answer all the questions. "So if you blame on him because you couldn't understand the course content, then it's definitely your problem."
reviews.comment_grading:
This course could be the hardest course I have taken so far. I think it's because the statistics stuffs are less trivial to me compare to linear algebra or matrix stuffs.

Grading turns out to be pretty fair.
If you really know all the points he mentioned, you could get most of the exam questions correct. Definitely an A range.
If you could know 70%~80% of the content, I think you could still get 40-60% of the questions in the exam, so probably a B range.
If you only know 50% of the content, then I would say you would probably fuck up in the exam and could only answer 1 to 2 questions. Definitely under B-.

Though UST grading is harsh. But doesn't it sound quite fair under this scheme?
reviews.comment_workload: Wordload is pretty light. The assignments are pretty hard but those are the only work.

reviews.author: aneagonh
reviews.title: Embraced by statistics and prooffff
reviews.comment_content:
- Preliminary
- Parameter estimation
- Hypothesis testing
- R coding (Dr. Yu will teach you how to code)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Dr. Yu's notes are comprehensive and he will add some proof during the lectures.
He is willing to answer your questions after classes.
reviews.comment_grading:
** Hard work will not change your destination for this course. ç·£ä»½åˆ°äº†, examè‡ªç„¶å°±æœƒè­˜åš.

If you are interested in statistics, you should feel ok with this course since it is fundamental to the statistics major.
reviews.comment_workload: Just a few assignments (4~5 questions each, less workload compared with Prof. Wong's version) and the exam (also fewer questions and completely different question types compared with Prof. Wong's version).
